1083432893005860864.text: "It’s more like a bribe or a tip. I’ve been thinking about postage stamps for a few weeks now, and the only issue is that if you pay for postage at a set #price, it’s a guarantee that it’ll go through... which sets some expectations we can’t meet..." - @celinepark13

1083425948752588801.text: “Replacing an entrenched metaphor strikes me as a hard prospect due to habit, cultural intransigence & the miscommunication issue (as 1 metaphor attempts to replace the other, & different people use different metaphors, leading to a point of temporary friction)“- @automaticyes

1083421492128481280.text: "Metaphors are cultural bridges. Different cultures build different bridges based on #environment and #community needs but the outcome is the same. People will use whatever means there is to get to the outcome. Is it adoption of metaphors or outcomes that people need?"- @NguyetV

1083417048032690176.text: "If we say users don't care about #gas, don't care about #keys, then it follows that they also don't care about #dapps, or #privacy, or taking down the #banks. But some people *do*, especially those who don't have banks or identities to begin with" - @JonnyAustinTX

1083413725053419522.text: Some thoughts: "why are we only focusing on what the “average user” wants without thinking about the native properties of web 3.0 again?  Why are we retrofitting our new tech into old paradigms without exploring what could make 3.0 brilliant on its own?" -@mentapurpura

1083413040870109184.text:
Any ideas? Jump in!

We have a 45+ comment thread going in our slack with 2 #design #researchers and 11 #designers discussing sweeping statements made about what #users need, is #gas an effective metaphor, why do we use metaphors, & alternate metaphors like stamps, tolls & bribeshttps://twitter.com/mentapurpura/status/1083390675905900544 …

2019 is here!  

We're so *pumped* to start the year with fresh goals + open hearts/minds!

share more research & WIP
help teams make better decisions for usability & adoptability
empower #designers

1079111928730079232.text:

Why do designers ask you to use divergent thinking when solving a problem?
